content:
I noticed in the PDF we got via email there was a mention of a Toolchain for AI movie creation, highlighted as an example for one of the tracks. Given the number of writers, filmmakers, and creative minds in our group, how about a thread on this topic?

This could be an interesting space for those interested in exploring innovative storytelling methods. With the rapid evolution of AI in creative industries, we could use this thread to share resources, insights, ideas for AI based film making.
AI Film Making

I‚Äôm co-hosting a free Britney themed workathon on Sep 15 if anyone‚Äôs in New York? Would be great to meet some folks ahead of time üôÇ https://lu.ma/gwfjxcuz?_bhlid=91e35742082e035e948aeaa3d69865fb775c5bf3&tk=3phShp

These projects are ideally all open source projects to allow for global access with out borders. Commercial projects can be build on top with a more nice approach. 

E.g. there was a VC funded tomatocrew style project targeting FAANG to reduce onboarding times for new hires. So value is several months of Amazon engineer salaries saved. Benefits those who don't really need it.

Ah and for education there is also tomatocrew.com which was supposed to pool people that go through the same MOOCs are work through the same books.

Inspiriration was a group pomodoro chat we had about a decade ago...
Great initiative!

Completely separate topic, something I've been always curious about academically speaking: Are there any professional lawyers in this group? It would be interesting to learn about how network and startup societies  -- which spawn membership globally -- could legally position themselves and protect themselves amid potentially stifling and conflicting nation state jurisdications as well as compliance measures. For example, if you were to start a network society as an entity, where do you register, and if you were to accept membership fees, where is that taxed?

Do you find a small developing country and base it on their jurisdiction (e.g. Palau), do you go to a special zone and fork jurisdication (e.g. Prospera), do you find a regulation transparent boutique country with global outreach (e.g. Singapore), or do you stick with where most of your members come from (e.g. USA)?
Awesome possum

For some more context:

telebrain.app: big ambition here, rather open source this as big tech wants you to waste life in their user interfaces (e.g. shorts in chatapps). keywords are self-botting for chat-apps, private networking (tailscale ftw), self-hosted llms infra (postgres with extensions: e.g. pgvector). leveraging big tech cloud (e.g., openai) is optional, not mandatory. decentralised data storage could also make sense plus using matrix as the messaging protocol layer. 

whydoc: rather boring but necessary. most innovation in data architecture on how to attach change over time to an object (block of text).

dailydo: should be a 1 day or max. weekend project. maybe as a progressive web app and with link into telebrain data warehouse.

Friend request me and DMs are open if that sparked some curiosity.
Chris's project list
Might get inspiration playing Settlers of Catan üëÄ

Hi all, I'm just throwing out few of the projects I'll be working on on campus as they may resonate a lot with you:

- telebrain.app: have made a landing page 4 years and been dabbling with it every so often. idea is to understand us humans as data generation machines and actually make that data actionable. so we can focus on generating data (aka living life) while processing of it is automated and can used to assist us in achieving personal goals. my main focus is to have it on private servers which are connected through encrypted networking to have sovereignity of own data and be more comfortable to store the stuff you don't want big tech to use against you. you may be able to expose certain data to others e.g. for on-chain proofs of work like we'll use at NS school (deep rabbit hole).
- whydoc (working name): project that allows to store meta information on blocks of text. think actually useful revision history for documents/contracts/etc.: which iteration has a sentence been gone through to understand the current final version better and not need to use mental capacity and trial and error for past thoughts.
- dailydo: todo list app for adhd folks - you can only add 3 tasks per day. past days are not visible but stored in database (so can be processed in e.g. telebrain). every day is a new chance to get unstuck and work on what is important.
I love it. Thank you!
I would love to do it but my September looks crazy (two travels before leaving Europe for Singapore). So chances for a call are not high in my case.

I‚Äôve gotten a lot of questions about why I suddenly moved to Singapore üòÇ For tech folks, it‚Äôs simple‚ÄîI just name-drop Balaji and mention it's his decentralized education program that blends global expertise with self-directed learning. They get it.

For everyone else, I explain that The Network School is like a high-tech Hogwarts where you learn real-world skills. Instead of a traditional classroom, it‚Äôs more like an open-world game where you pick your own learning path, connecting with global experts and meet like-minded people. It‚Äôs basically a ‚Äúchoose-your-own-adventure‚Äù for education.
Yes. And I think it is also important for the NS to find a way to communicate this project in a manner that the general public is able to understand. And it doesn't sound too niche and distant.
Most of my friends don't understand Blockchain. In fact I don't understand it myself üòâ
On virtual capital: it‚Äôs the place to which the citizens go to, to self-organize. You could say this discord is exactly that.

Every campus, a physical + digital node in the Network State.

In around 30 seconds or less (60-80 words) explain, to a colleague with no idea, what The Network School is.

NS staff has stayed in Forest City overnight many times, and we haven't noticed serious mosquitoes or bugs in places which are regularly cleaned. Malaysia has tropical weather, so it's a good idea to bring bug spray for the outdoors.

Hey amazing people! I'm hosting a digital nomad meet-up in Singapore on the 21st of September at 9 am. You are more than welcome to join If you're in town too. The basic format is just grab a coffee and swap stories! ‚òïüòä Feel free to let me know if you'd like to join for the morning coffee and I'll send you the location.
Meet-up on September 21st

I had a few questions while I was reading the first chapters, maybe they will be answered later in the book but I'll still put them here if anyone wants to discuss.
- What is the significance of a capital or more specifically a virtual capital wrt a network state. Needing and setting up a capital(virtual) comes up many times.
- Is the population/real-estate/Annual income metric only important? Are there other metrics of importance?
- Why do we discuss annual income here, not net worth, assets held like gold/BTC etc.
- In the network state in 1000 words, 3rd step of the 7 steps of getting there:
"Build trust offline and a cryptoeconomy online, Begin holding in person meetups in the physical world, of increasing scale and duration, while simultaneously building an internal economy  using cryptocurrency". Is this where what we are doing with the network school?

I started chapter 2 as well, but it is even more information-dense. Would take some time to go through
- Offense Archaeology and weaponized history were really interesting, I had never thought of it this way. What would be some go-to must-read history books to get up to speed?

I am not sure, I think any form of content (audio, video, text) would do. Most viral possibilities would be short videos I think, also depends on what impact you want it to have. Think in terms of startup society, how do we make it viral? How did El Salvador put itself on the map again?

You can operate a US LLC without the LLC itself being subject to federal tax in the US, provided there are no US operations. Having clients in the US is not US operations. An LLC owned by a single Owner would be a "Disregarded Entity" whereby the distribution of profits is only subject to tax in your tax residency.

This is part of my setup. I'm a non-resident alien in the US, and not a US Person. But I can still operate a Wyoming LLC, have business banking, personal banking and credit.

FWIW Wyoming is cheaper and easier to operate than Delaware. But both work.

Happy to discuss further how this works, especially when we get there in person. Just keep in mind i'm not a lawyer, accountant, or tax expert. I'm just a software engineer interested in self-sovereignty which includes some of these topics üôÇ

For those interested in the world events, we are in the 4th turning, known as the ‚Äúcrisis‚Äù period. Where old institutions collapse / reform and new ones get built. It‚Äôs estimated to end by approx 2030. Trustless tech will rule supreme in the next decade, obviously get yourself some bitcoin. I think it‚Äôs also the end of Zionism as we know it - it‚Äôll be studied in school by our children as a ‚Äúwtf‚Äù moment that controlled the entire west - alternative nations like the Middle East, India, SG, Malaysia, El Salvador etc will be the places to be. Not the west. Ultimately I am excited for this global change that‚Äôs taking place and is already pre written - question is, how the F do I start / who can I work with
This is what decentralisation is going to solve. Who of us are going to help build this üòÇ / or who‚Äôs working on similar big problems

Hi @undefined You might find this recent Global Crypto Tax Report useful, from Web3accountant & Elven in Singapore. I contributed. I'm an Australian chartered tax adviser & accountant dealing with clients who set up overseas since 2008, and SG is popular choice for its tax benefits for startups, stable economy and has geographical advantage for us. Although it's been many years since I formally studied SG & USA tax, USA tax is very hard, and I'm looking at SG for my own company with the guidance of my SG professional connections to establish it. Let's chat at NS, with others who may be trying to navigate the same things as us.
https://web3accountant.online/web3-accountant-global-crypto-tax-report-2024/

Thanks all for this channel, looking forward to a transformative time on our journey together.

Wanted to share a few hacks I have gathered on a little journey so far, so maybe potentially we could together hack Nirvana ;).

Alignment - The more aligned I became, the more comfortable I became in the sitting posture, the deeper the rabbit hole went. Yoga, Climbing, other movement forms that stretch and tone seem to help.

Shunyata - Some Buddhist schools teach a technique called Shunyata, and it is practiced in conjunction with Vipassana. It is basically a meditation on emptiness. The final sutra in shiva sutras called "Enter Space, Supportless, Eternal, Still" evokes this similarly. Doing Shunyata makes you very, very still, almost in a state of letting go and really entering eternal space. Later when vipassana is done, there's a very different quality and depth to it. 

Given our diverse group from different regions and faiths, it would be fascinating to share and explore new practices. Some ideas:

Interfaith kirtan sessions?
Trying new techniques from different traditions
Exploring movement-based meditations (Qi Gong, Tai Chi, Whirling, Yoga, etc.)

So you need to weight the tax cost and benefit when deciding

Remember that Delaware does not mean tax free. US tax law is complicated due to it being a UNITED STATES. 

If you have clients, employees, or conduct significant business activities in other states, those states may require you to pay state income tax, sales tax, or other applicable taxes. The specific tax obligations depend on the laws of each state where you conduct business.

It is actually super easy to set up a Delaware entity from outside of the country as well. If you want to present yourself as a local business, you could certainly set up a Delaware entity without yourself ever stepping on the soil of US.

I have a completely different off-topic question, but I thought I will leverage the groups knowledge here. 
80% of my clients are from the US, I currently have my business in India, but there are 2 reasons to open a company elsewhere:
1. Tax benefits
2. Client Perspective (They like to work with local businesses, and tend to pay higher)

I am confused between Singapore and US. Singapore is more accessible to me, has less tax compared to India. US has most of my clients has 0% tax in Delaware, it is less accessible though. 

Do any of you have knowledge or experience, would love to get some insights!
